title: 【告美國政府】華裔天文學家被誣指間諜 「未能重返氣象局 生活盡毀」

replies.msg:
美國法庭去年裁定，2014年被當局毫無根據指控為間諜而錯誤拘捕的美籍華裔天文學家陳霞芬(Sherry Chen)，是「美國司法嚴重不公正的受害人」，並下令恢復她在國家氣象局(NWS)的職位，並支付她被解僱期間的薪酬連福利。但同年6月18日，不服判決的商務部提起上訴，陳霞芬至今未能重返國家氣象局的工作崗位，被誣指為間諜，令她生活盡毀。
於當地時間23日，陳霞芬法律維權基金會發佈消息，指律師團隊已於18日，向美國俄亥俄南區聯邦地區法院提起聯邦訴訟，狀告美國政府對陳霞芬惡意起訴和錯誤逮捕。
陳霞芬是美國國家氣象局轄下的國家海洋及大氣部門職員。2012年5月24日，被舉報，稱她「雖是美國公民，但卻是中國人」，指她有間諜嫌疑。
2013年6月11日，陳霞芬在工作單位被美國商務部派來的探員盤問了7小時。
2014年10月20日，陳霞芬被指偷取有關堤壩的敏感資料而被拘捕，但美國聯邦檢控官在2015年3月撤銷她的控罪。
2016年3月11日，陳霞芬被美國商務部(國家象局主管單位)解僱。
2018年4月，審理聯邦政府僱員行政處分的「考勤保護委員會」(MSPB)首席行政法官施羅德(Michele Schroeder)裁定商務部無理解僱，下令恢復她在國家氣象局(NWS)的職位。2018年6月18日，不服判決的美國商務部提起上訴，令陳霞芬未能重返她在國家氣象局的工作崗位。
陳霞芬的代表律師Michele Young表示，陳霞芬被指是間諜是毫無事實依據、明顯帶有種族偏見的指控。「政府官員隱藏了明明可以證明當事人無辜的證據，浪費數十萬美元納稅人的錢，試圖證明一個『中國人』是間諜。」為彰顯尊嚴、公平和美國價值觀，必須為陳霞芬伸張正義，因為發生在陳身上的事，也不應該發生在任何一個美國人身上。

Chen’s ordeal began after she took a trip back to China in April 2012 to visit her parents and family in Beijing for three weeks, the judge wrote.

At the request of her nephew, Chen, a naturalized U.S. citizen working for the National Weather Service in Ohio, agreed to meet in China with a former classmate who served as the vice minister for water resources in Beijing, the document said.

The two spent most of the meeting discussing a contract dispute involving the nephew’s father-in-law, but the vice minister also asked Chen about her work in the U.S., the judge wrote in her order. Questions included how the federal and local governments shared costs to repair aging dams and the total water volume in the U.S.

After returning back to the U.S., Chen initially searched a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers website on dams during her lunch hour to find answers, the ruling said. At that time, she did not search the government-restricted databases because she did not have a password. Also, she knew those sections would not be the place to find answers for the Chinese official, the judge wrote.

Chen did think that parts of the database requiring a password may have information that could help with her own work, so she inquired with a colleague about accessing them, the ruling said.

That coworker shared an “office” password with Chen and sat down to show her the database, the document said. The pair downloaded one file related to Ohio dams, part of Chen’s work.

As for questions related to the Chinese official’s inquiry, all of which the ruling notes was public information, Chen sent an email to her supervisor asking for help, the document said.

The supervisor, in turn, contacted someone at the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers for assistance. The corps employee, who spoke briefly with Chen by phone, subsequently alerted a corps’ security officer about their exchange.
